data.event: The county was created in 1867 and named for Abraham Lincoln.

event.title: was created by an act of the West Virginia Legislature on February 23, 1867

data.event: Lincoln County was created by an act of the West Virginia Legislature on February 23, 1867, from parts of Boone, Cabell, Kanawha and Putnam counties.
By 1869, the county had returned much of its Putnam County territory and absorbed the northern portion of Logan County and a portion of Wayne County.

event.title: 1869, Harts Creek Township (later district) was created

data.event: In 1869, Harts Creek Township (later district) was created from this latter region.
Hamlin, seat of government for the county, was established in 1853.

event.title: grown in the area near present-day West Hamlin, in 1799

data.event: They cultivated 20 acres (81,000 m2) of corn, the first ever grown in the area near present-day West Hamlin, in 1799.
Later that year, they returned to eastern Virginia to get their families.

event.title: built cabins in the county around 1800

data.event: They built cabins in the county around 1800.
About 1804, William Wirt Brumfield settled at the mouth of Big Ugly Creek.
